meta.title: Upper Limb (Fracture Sc Humerus Till Fingers)

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl fell from a height while playing and sustained an extension-type supracondylar humerus fracture with a neurologic deficit. An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following muscles is most likely affected?

options.label: C
options.text: Flexor carpi radialis and Flexor carpi ulnaris

options.label: D
options.text: Flexor digitorum profundus to small / ring finger

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Flexor pollicis longus Anterior interosseous nerve injury is the most common nerve injury seen in extension-type supracondylar humerus fractures in children and the Ulnar nerve is most frequently injured in flexion-type injuries. The anterior interosseous nerve innervates flexor pollicis longus, flexor digitorum profundus to the index and long fingers and pronator quadratus.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Extensor digitorum communis is supplied by Posterior Interosseous Nerve Option: C. Flexor Carpi radialis is supplied by Median Nerve , Flexor Carpi Ulnaris to small / ring fingers is supplied by Ulnar Nerve Option: D. FCU and FDP to small / ring fingers are supplied by Ulnar Nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following fractures is known as Rolando's fracture?

options.label: A
options.text: Fracture base of the fifth metatarsal

options.label: B
options.text: Comminuted intra intra-articular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal

options.label: C
options.text: Fracture of the neck of the second metatarsal

questions.correct_answer: B. Comminuted intra intra-articular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Comminuted intra intra-articular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal Bennet's fracture is also intra- While Bennet is an oblique fracture, Rolando is a ‘T’ or ‘Y’ shaped fracture. Also, Bennet is generally a displaced fracture owing to pull by the muscle Abductor pollicis longus.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Not fracture base of 5th metatarsal which is Jones fracture Option: C. Not Fracture neck of the second metatarsal Option: D. Not Fracture of ulnar styloid

questions.text: Dislocation of the inferior radioulnar joint and fracture head of the radius is known as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Essex Lopresti dislocation Comminuted fracture of the head of the radius with dislocation of the inferior radio-ulnar joint is known as Essex Lopresti fracture-dislocation.

Highyeild:

ESSEX LOPRESTI LESION Injury to interosseous membrane Distal ulna subluxation Fracture Radial head

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Not Monteggia fracture-dislocation Option: B. Not Galeazzi fracture-dislocatio Option: D. Not Soprano's fracture-dislocation

questions.text: Fractures involving the dorsal articular margin of the distal radius and associated with subluxation or dislocation of the carpus dorsally are referred to as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dorsal Barton's fracture Fractures involving the volar articular margin of the distal radius with subluxation of the carpus are called Barton's fracture.

Highyeild:

BARTON’S Partial intra-articular of distal radius with subluxation or dislocation of carpals dorasally Types: - volar - Dorsal

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Not Smith fracture Option: C. -Not Chauffeur's fracture Option: D. -Not Colles fracture. COLLE'S SMITH ← Distal end of radius → ← Extra-articular → # DER at its cortico cancellous junction around 2 cm from the distal articular surface with typical displacement. Displacement: LIDS Palmar displacement (of distal fragment) Lateral displacement/ tilt Impaction Dorsal displacement / tilt Supination Complications: Stiffness (MC) Malunion → Dinner fork deformity Rupture of EPL tendon Sudeck's dystrophy Carpal tunnel syndrome Carpal instability

questions.text: The blood supply of the scaphoid is through which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Distal pole The vascular pedicle of the scaphoid shows some variation but it commonly enters the scaphoid through the distal pole. Vascular supply to the proximal pole is thus compromised in fractures through the waist. Thus avascular necrosis and subsequent osteoarthritis of the wrist are common complications following a scaphoid fracture.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Blood supply is retrograde, so through the distal pole and through the proximal pole Option: B. Not through tubercle Option: C. Not through waist

questions.text: The nerve most likely to be injured in shoulder dislocation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Axillary nerve Option: A. The axillary nerve is most commonly injured following anterior shoulder dislocation.

Highyeild:

Complications of shoulder dislocation: a. Early: i. Injury to axillary nerve (deltoid paralysis and small area of anaesthesia over lateral aspect of shoulder). ii. Rx: conservative iii. The prognosis is good. b. Late: i. Commonest joint to undergo recurrent dislocation ii. This results from the following causes: a) Anatomically unstable joint e.g. in Marfan’s syndrome b) Inadequate Rx of the first episode c) Epileptic patient.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Brachial nerve injury is rare during shoulder dislocation Option: C. Nerve to s erratus anterior injury is rare during shoulder dislocation Option: D. The axillary nerve is most commonly injured following anterior Shoulder dislocation.

questions.text: ‘Three point’ relation is used to differentiate Supracondylar fracture from fracture of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Three-point relationships are seen around the elbow Medial epicondyle Lateral epicondyle Tip of olecranon Important to diagnose injuries around the elbow Elbow when flexed at 90 degrees, three landmarks form an isosceles triangle And when extended form a straight horizontal line Maintained in Supracondylar fracture

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. B, C- Three-point relationship not maintained in Fracture lateral condyle humerus, Fracture medial condyle humerus, Elbow dislocation.

options.label: A
options.text: Fracture distal radius with inferior radioulnar dislocation

options.label: B
options.text: Fracture distal end of radius with dorsal displacement and angulation

options.label: D
options.text: Fracture extra-articular surface of the base of first metacarpal

questions.correct_answer: D. Fracture extra-articular surface of the base of first metacarpal
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fracture extra-articular surface of the base of first metacarpal Option: D. Fracture articular surface of the base of first metacarpal=Rolando’s fracture.

Highyeild:

REMEMBER: List of Important Named Fractures: FRACTURE NAME INVOLVED BONE Hangman's fracture Pedicle lamina of C2 vertebra Malgaigne's fracture Bumper fracture Pelvic ring disruption with both pubic rami and sacroiliac injury on the same side. Comminuted fracture of lateral condyle of tibia Cottons fracture Trimalleolar ankle fracture Pott's fracture Bimalleolar ankle fracture March fracture Stress fracture of shaft of 2 ^ (nd) metatarsal Aviators fracture Neck of talus Jone's fracture Base of 5 th (th) metatarsal Rolando fracture Base of 1 st pi metacarpal, extra articular Bennett's fracture Base of 1 st metacarpal, intraarticular Boxers fracture Neck of 5 th metacarpal Smith's fracture Nightstick fracture Distal radial-extra articular with volar tilt of distal fragment Isolated fracture shaft ulna Monteggia fracture Proximal one third of ulna with dislocation of head of radius Galleazzi fracture Distal one third of radius with dislocation of distal radioulnar jt Colles' fracture Distal radius-extraarticular with dorsal tilt of distal fragment Chauffeur's fracture Radial styloid fracture Barton's fracture Distal radius-intra articular Baby car fracture Distal end humerus with proximal radius ulna (Side swipe injury) Massonaise fracture Neck of fibula Pilons fracture Distal end of tibia Chopart's fracture Fracture dislocation through intertarsal joint Clay Shoveller's fracture Avulsion of C7-T1 spinous process Jefferson's fracture Body of C1 vertebra Jarjavay fracture Fracture of maxillary spine to vomer Chevallet fracture Fracture of maxillary spine to root of nose

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Fracture distal radius with inferior radioulnar dislocation=Galeazzi fracture. GALEAZZI Reverse Monteggia distal 1/3 radius Dislocation of distal ulna of necessity Option: B. Fracture distal end of radius with dorsal displacement and angulation=Colle’s fracture COLLE'S SMITH ← Distal end of radius → ← Extra-articular → DER at its cortico cancellous junction around 2 cm from the distal articular surface with typical displacement. Displacement: LIDS Palmar displacement (of distal fragment) Lateral displacement/ tilt Impaction Dorsal displacement / tilt Supination Complications: Stiffness (MC) Malunion → Dinner fork deformity Rupture of EPL tendon Sudeck's dystrophy Carpal tunnel syndrome Carpal instability Option: C. Fracture radial styloid=Chauffer’s fracture

questions.text: The “Lift off” test is done for which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Subscapularis Resisted internal rotation (subscapularis) = “ Lift-off test ” Empty Can Test For: External Impingement Posture: Patient seated with arm in 90° abduction, 30° horizontal adduction and full internal rotation Test: Resist abduction/flexion Positive: Pain in the shoulder; muscle weakness Modification: Repeat with full external rotation to reduce pain

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: C. Resisted abduction (supraspinatus) = “Empty Can Test”, Jobe’s Test (thumbs down, arms forward 30°) and Drop-Arm Test, Speed’s Test and Yergason’s Test for biceps Option: B. & D. Resisted external rotation (infraspinatus, teres minor)
